title: Robert Altman (1996) Kansas City
description:
The jazz world of 1930s Kansas City serves as the backdrop for an offbeat story of kidnapping, political corruption, and 

organized crime in director Robert Altman&#039;s loving but unsentimental look at his childhood hometown. The film&#039;s intricate 

story is triggered by petty thief Johnny O&#039;Hara (Dermot Mulroney), who aims for a big score by trying to rob notorious 

crime boss Seldom Seen (Harry Belafonte), only to end up Seen&#039;s captive. In fear for her husband&#039;s life, Johnny&#039;s wife 

Blondie (Jennifer Jason Leigh) decides to take action. Following an eccentric personal logic, she takes as a hostage the wife 

of a prominent local politician, in hopes of getting the woman&#039;s husband to help; unfortunately, he is on the road with an 

upcoming presidential campaign, putting a major hitch in Blondie&#039;s plans. The film moves freely among its idiosyncratic 

characters in an overt attempt to mimic the improvisational structure of 1930s jazz. Indeed, many of the film&#039;s most 

important sequences take place in Seldom Seen&#039;s club, with contemporary jazz greats imitating the period&#039;s master 

musicians and Harry Belafonte shining as the magnetic, menacing Seen. The central narrative never achieves the seemingly 

effortless integration of Altman&#039;s greatest works, but those who share Altman&#039;s obvious passion for the period and its 

music will find much to admire.
